data.message: Yeah, I can see niche uses for Glass in fields like medicine or police work, but I don't see my parents or grandparents ever walking around with them.

He means new concepts or ways of doing things, iPad and iPhone were innovative but were just a new version of phone and laptop, things people already were using everyday. No one really has been going around with personal assistants strapped to their heads before, new concepts need time for people to adjust to and some people don't like adjusting.
Actually tablet technology is a perfect example of a product that dragged for years before gaining widespread acceptance.

Nicholas Rios Exactly. Microsoft was selling tablet pc's for years before iPads or even iPhones were on the radar. They weren't very good, but they existed.
Apple had the Newton out for a while before Palm turned PDAs into a self-named category.
Microsoft, Blackberry, Palm, and Nokia all had smartphone OSes years before Apple "created" the smartphone.
My guess is that someone else will tweak the Google Glass thing into a more human-friendly product. 8 years from now people will be saying, "Google did that first".
Thomas Osborne  wearing a webcam like a dork on your face is hardly a "new concept"
Nicholas Rios On what planet. Here it took of immediately. What tablet are you talking about?
Andrew Sands microsoft had the first tablet in the 90's, it did not take off immediately
Nicholas Rios  Yeah, somehow people don't understand that there were mp3 players, tablets, and touchscreen phones before Apple's versions.
Agreed. The iPhone and iPad were both very well received. Apple had record-breakig debuts for both.
Nicholas Rios - yeah, until Apple released one.
People DID make fun of the Segway, and look how widespread, oh wait.

Could not agree more with your statement. There is something called " timing the market." You can't force the market to adopt something like this, not-to-mention pay $1,500 for something they don't need. There is no use case where you actually need this. Apple timed the market perfectly by launching the iPad after the iPhone. Reversing that order of those two products, we would not have seen the same adoption rate. People are on their phones all of the time and they're not on their tablets all of the time. Wearing something on your face and paying nearly 4-5-6 times the price? This isn't a case of people not wanting to adopt it. It's their failure to understand the market, develop a use case to create demand. Google needs to learn how to launch products better and on the case, they launched a product to the public, they reacted and now people in beta aren't participating because of the blow back. This is like Microsoft's surface table. Too expensive and the form factor is wrong. Three years later, Apple launches iPad. Perfect timing, perfect form factor because people saw the need.
